name: Remo Fernandes
description:
'''Lu√≠s Remo de Maria Bernardo Fernandes''' (born 8 May 1953) is an Indian-Portuguese singer and musician. Known as a pioneer of [[Indian pop music]], he performs [[Pop music|pop]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Fusion music|Indian fusion]], and is also a film [[playback singer]]. His musical work is a fusion of many different cultures and styles that he has been exposed to as a child in [[Goa]] and in his later travels around the world. Such influences include [[Music of Goa|Goan]] and [[Portuguese music]], [[Sega music]] (from [[Mauritius]] and [[Seychelles]]), [[African music]], [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]] (from Spain and South America), the music of erstwhile European communist states, those of the dance halls from [[Jamaica]] and [[Soca music|Soca]] (from [[Trinidad and Tobago]]).

Writing and singing songs in English made his success more rare and distinctive in the context of the [[Bollywood]]-dominated, [[Hindi language]]-based, occasionally even [[disco]] music scene that was popular in the 1980s and 1990s. His compositions in English, reflecting life and socio-political happenings in India with which every Indian could identify. His Hindi pop/rock and film songs became instant hits with the Indian masses, earning him [[Music recording certification|Gold, Platinum and Double Platinum Discs]]. A popular stage performer in India, he has also taken part in many music festivals around the world. He has performed with members of international groups such as [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]], [[Led Zeppelin]] and [[Queen (band)|Queen]].

He now writes and sings his songs in five different languages: English, Hindi, French, [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Konkani language|Konkani]]. He also holds an [[Overseas Citizenship of India]] card since acquiring Portuguese citizenship.
